awd_titl_txt: Molecular Level Understanding of Dynamic Speciation to Inform Complex Reaction Pathways and Control the Rational Synthesis of Ternary Semiconductor Nanoparticles
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry Program in the Division of Chemistry, Dr. Amy Prieto of Colorado State University is developing a synthetic toolkit for understanding and controlling the reactivity of selenium species that can direct the synthesis of phase pure ternary semiconductor nanoparticles. These nanomaterials, which are composed of non-toxic, earth-abundant elements, have the potential to offer tunable optoelectronic properties that could be exploited in photovoltaic devices. Dr. Prieto involves high school, undergraduate, and graduate students in this research. The Prieto research team is also developing hands-on learning kits for middle school students that focus on solar cells to engage them in key energy topics. 

This research involves elucidating how the precursor to monomer transformation of Se powder in high boiling point surfactants can yield phase-pure ternary semiconductor nanoparticles. This includes probing the speciation of reactive components that lead to phase pure copper selenophosphate nanoparticles by focusing on the Lewis acidity and basicity of selenium monomers, understanding these synthetic parameters to controllably access phosphorous deficient metastable C/P/Se nanoparticles, and extrapolating this chemistry to synthesize a new silver compound that contains both phosphorus and selenium. This research is focusing on a diverse range of tools to identify solution species and crystalline products under both in-situ reaction conditions and post-synthesis. By developing this tool kit for the synthesis of semiconductor nanoparticles, reaction pathways for pure phase ternary and quaternary nanoparticles with tunable composition, structure, and surface chemistry are expected and these could be exploited in future photovoltaics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Although theoretical predictions for compounds with improved properties for a wide variety of applications are improving rapidly, even the most accurate predictions do not come with a clear recipe. There is still a significant challenge in developing efficient, rational approaches for making new materials with useful properties. Although there have been significant advances in making materials on the nanoscale, these reactions are often discovered and optimized primarily by trial and error. What is needed for the field to advance is an understanding of how much of each reactant is important (to control the efficiency of the reaction), methods to observe these reactions in real time, and libraries of reactions, which connect intermediates in various ways in order to be generally useful.

We reported the first solution-based synthesis of phase pure Cu3PSe4 nanoparticles, which have been predicted by theorists to be an attractive compound for photovoltaic applications.  This is a challenging compound to make from solution because it combines elements that have very different reactivity. The number of accessible ternary compounds in the Cu/P/Se phase space is significant, and there are thermodynamically stable binary compounds that could be impurities resulting from the synthesis. The main successes from this project were in developing an atom economical route to our desired compound, developing reagents that could be tracked in real time, and developing a better understanding of the role of the solvent.

This project was an effective tool for recruiting and retaining talented students.  A key goal in our group is how to continue to effectively incorporate students from high school through undergraduate and graduate students into the research.  We participated actively in the Research Experience for Undergraduates program at CSU, and we disseminated what we learned widely, both through publications and lectures at conferences.  Prof. Prieto is also very fortunate in that she is routinely invited to give talks to general audiences. The project is well suited to be used as an example of basic research that can be easily linked to an application that a wide audience can be interested in, with the goal of clean energy production and storage as an urgent need for society as we work to diversify our toolkit for producing and storing energy. 

 


Last Modified: 03/07/2025
Modified by: Amy Lucia Prieto
